===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|ゆか}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=ゆか}}. Attested in the {{m|ja|日本書紀|tr=Nihon Shoki}}, completed in 720 and one of the earliest works written in Japanese (see [[Wikipedia:Nihon Shoki]]), with a meaning of {{m|en|bed}}.

According to the {{lang|ja|和句解}} (''Wakuge''), published in 1668 by early Edo-period scholar Matsunaga Teitoku ({{lang|ja|松永貞徳}}; see [[Wikipedia:ja:松永貞徳]]), derives from ゆか (''yuka'') as the {{m|ja|未然形|tr=[[mizenkei]]||[[irrealis]] form}} stem of the verb {{m|ja|行く|tr=yuku||to go}} of an original meaning similar to "not going", in reference to a place where one sits down to rest.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|ゆか|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR,NHK}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|ゆか}}

# the [[floor]] (the bottom surface of a room)
# a [[bed]]
# {{lb|ja|sort=ゆか|theater}} a raised area of a [[stage]] where a [[presenter]] or [[musician]] sits
# a raised [[platform]] erected along the Kamo River in Kyōto in summer, used as an outdoor [[tea]] shop or [[restaurant]]

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=k|とこ}}
From {{etyl|ojp|ja|sort=とこ}}. Cognate with {{m|ja|所|tr=tokoro||place}}. Attested since at least the Nara period, appearing in the {{m|ja|万葉集|tr=Man'yōshū}}, completed in 759 (see [[Wikipedia:Man'yōshū]]).<ref name="KDJ">{{R:Kokugo Dai Jiten}}</ref>

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=k|とこ|acc=0|acc_ref=DJR,NHK}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|とこ}}

# a [[raised]] [[platform]] roughly 30cm tall used in dirt-floored rooms as a [[seat]]
# a raised area on which to sleep: a [[bed]]
# the [[floor]]
# [[tatami]] mats
# the seat of an [[oxcart]]
# short for {{m|ja|床間}} / {{m|ja|床の間|tr=toko no ma}}: an [[alcove]] with a raised floor along one wall of a traditional Japanese living room
# an alcove with a raised floor used as a [[study]]: see {{m|ja|付書院|tr=tsuke shoin}}
# a [[box seat]], such as at a [[parade]], [[theater]], or [[stadium]]
# short for {{m|ja|床店|tr=tokomise}}: a [[stall]] with a raised floor used as a store
# short for {{m|ja|床屋|tr=tokoya}}: a [[barbershop]], from how such shops were historically often ''tokomise''
# short for {{m|ja|床船梁|tr=toko funabari}}, {{m|ja|舵床|tr=kajidoko}}: the large [[wooden]] [[beam]] at the very [[aft]] of a traditional [[wood]]-[[hulled]] Japanese [[ship]], upon which the [[rudder]] is seated
# the [[heel]] of a [[plough]]; the part of the bottom of a plough that touches the ground and guides the [[ploughshare]]
# short for {{m|ja|苗床|tr=naedoko}}: a [[seedbed]]
# short for {{m|ja|鉄床}}, {{m|ja|金床|tr=kanatoko}}: an [[anvil]]
